q.p: THY country's happineſs is truſted to thy care—O happy country, bleſt UNITED STATES!

My life is nothing but a ſcene of woe—How often have I wiſh'd the gordian knot of matrimony were again untied!—For MRS. JENSON—Vaſhti like, muſt be ador'd, or elſe—Farewell to all domeſtic eaſe—I'm almoſt weary of her—She muſt and ſhall ſubmit.

God knows I am, at heart, a friend to none on earth, except my own beloved ſelf—I've ſworn his ruin, ever ſince her father gave her to his rival arms—My plan ſucceeds—Yet what a wretch I am, to triumph thus, at the misfortunes of my fellow men!—'Tis truly deviliſh, I confeſs it is—Well, well, I'll think of it another time.
I long to wear the ſhining crown of fame—And yet, I wiſh I could have liv'd contented here—I ſhall be ruin'd, after all.
This is the conſequence of being brib'd, to murder honeſt people in their ſleep!

I gave my hand, though nature held my heart—His 〈◊〉 never harmonize with mine—Good heav'ns! How complaiſant the MAJOR is!—I wiſh I were his bride—It makes me curſe my fate—I'm wrong'd, neglected and deſpis'd—O cruel huſband! O unfeeling man!—He has debas'd himſelf, to ruin me—My cruel father too—But he is gone, and all are gone—I've not a friend on earth—Alas! I am undone—Deteſted wretch! Prove falſe himſelf, th • n lay that charge on me!—I'll be his death, or 〈◊〉 myſelf.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: GOOD friends, who come to hear and ſee the play,
Our Author bids me juſt appear and ſay,
The characters which he unfolds to view,
Are not ſublime, although he thinks them true.
He wakes no Grecian here from his tomb,
Or ſlumbering patriot of imperial Rome;
He calls no Gallic Prince or Britiſh lord,
To walk the ſtage, and wield the tragic ſword▪
Employs no Waſhington to aid his plan,
Or faithleſs Arnold—that diſgrace to man:—
But ſhows the miſeries of a man and wife,
A ſimple circumſtance of common life.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: MR. WORTHY, a Member of Congreſs.
MR. JENSON, appointed a foreign Commiſſioner.
MR. LYNDALL, a Merchant of Boſton.

div.head: ACT I.
div.l: ONCE more, my ſoul, releas'd from ſleep,
And all the horrors of terrific dreams,
I riſe before the Sun; and here alone,
Amidſt this garden's ſolitary walks,
Await the earlieſt beam, that from the eaſt,
May come, to uſher in approaching day:
Thrice hapleſs day to me! For now the year,
Revolving thrice, has roll'd the ſeaſons round;
Since, in obedience to my father's will,
I yielded to the matrimonial yoke.
At each return of this unhappy day,
The ſun (methinks) ſhould be o'erſpread with clouds,
And ſympathizing nature rob'd in black.
Little, ah! little did I then conceive
The ills that haunt a mercenary match.
I envy now the homeleſs vagabond,
Who begs her daily bread from door to door;
For ſurely ſhe is bleſt with ſweet content:
While, in the harneſs of a nuptial vow,
I drag along the heavy lead of life,
Join'd with a partner, whom my ſoul deteſts.
Unthinking maid! Why did my tongue conſent,
To change my name, my fortune and my all?
Againſt my own deſire, I gave my hand,
(Oh! let oblivion blaſt the painful thought!)
I gave my hand, though nature held my heart.
Thence I begin the aera of my woes.
Had I then known, what torments would enſue,
I ſhould (unnatural thought) I ſhould have dar'd
His moſt indignant wrath. Relentleſs fire,
What had I done, to forfeit thy regard?
How couldſt thou trifle with thy daughter's life,
And bid me wed deſpair? Sure, 'twas unkind.
Yet, gracious heav'n, forgive the cruel deed!
And ſhall not I? Yes, O my father, now
No more my guide, ſince death hath clos'd thine eyes,
And laid thee mouldering in the ſilent grave;
Though, when alive, thy pretence was my dread,
Repoſe in peace: No more I fear thy rage.
I will not violate thy ſacred duſt,
Or call thy ſlumbering memory into mind:
Adieu to all my pleaſing dreams of bliſs,
And hope, that ſweetneſs life's inſipid cup.
The gall of ſorrow tinctures all my life,
And grief embitters ev'n the bittereſt dregs.
My fate is fixt, beyond redreſs. [Weeps.]
What! Whence is this?
Why, Betty, dare you come, without command,
To interrupt my morning thoughts?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: I come, through fear that thou art ill,
To walk abroad, at ſuch an early hour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: My, more than maid—my ever-conſtant friend,
Such kind attention claims my gratitude.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: Thy looks and voice,
Thy burſting ſighs and overflowing tears,
Confirm the tidings, that my fears foretold.
Art thou not faint? It ſeems to me, thou art.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Aye, faint indeed.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: I am afraid,
Thoſe fits of faintneſs, which thou often haſt,
On ſudden ſhocks, are coming on again.
Shall I not run, and fetch thy cordial drops? [Going.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Stay, Betty, ſtay, 'twould be to no effect,
If all the Atlantic ocean were refin'd
To cordials, and adminiſter'd to me;
It could not, for a moment, eaſe my pain.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: What ſhall we do? I fear the conſequence,
For ſeveral days thou haſt appear'd unwell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: I'll tell you, honeſt Betty, once for all;
I'm ſick at heart, though otherwiſe in health.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: How great muſt be that grief,
Which ſpreads this lowering cloud upon thy brow!

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Ah! great indeed—too great to be endur'd!
My ſun of joy has long withdrawn from view;
While hope, which wanes and waxes, like the moon,
And never ſhines, but with a borrow'd light,
Reflected faintly from ſome diſtant good—
Ev'n glimmering hope is totally eclips'd,
And every ſtar of comfort diſappears.
In vain you'll ſtrive, to chear my gloomy thoughts:
For ſtill the darkeſt ſhades of midnight are
No more than twilight, to this night of woe.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: Pray, gentle lady, ſtifle theſe complaints!
Though melancholy overſpreads thy ſoul,
And reigns in darkneſs there; yet day will riſe,
More pleaſing, for this antecedent gloom.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I wiſh it may; but can't believe it will.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: It ſurely muſt. Come, wake to chearful thoughts,
And yield no more to leaden grief; for, ſee!
The ſun peeps over yonder eaſtern hill,
And heaves his head majeſtic up to view.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Theſe eyes have been ſo long ſuffus'd with tears,
The ſun affects my fight, as through a miſt,
And gives but little pleaſure to my ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: Thy tears have flow'd too long:
Come, condeſcend to brighten up thoſe eyes.
Since nature all around thee ſmiles,
Why wilt thou not partake the ſpreading joy?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: O that ſuch thoughts could bury up my pains!
But all attempts, like theſe, though meant for good,
Can only ſtir the coals of diſcontent;
And ſerve, to heat again, with ſeven-fold rage,
The glowing paſſion, that enflames my breaſt.
'Tis true, all nature ſmiles, and thus proclaims
Her joy: Yet ſmiling thus, in joyful mood,
She only mocks at my extreme diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: Indulgent made in, wilt thou always live,
Among thy friends, thus penſive and forlorn?
I've ſcarcely ſeen a ſmile upon thy face,
Since the completion of thy bridal day.
I am a witneſs to thy diſcontent,
As once I ſhar'd in thy delightful ſcenes:
Thy virgin checks then wore a ſmiling bluſh;
Contentment ſparkled from thoſe jetty eyes,
And every word beſpoke a mind at eaſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Thoſe days are paſt, and will no more return.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: Yet other days ſucceed, and why not other joys?
Does marriage always throw a damp on I ſo,
Or is this plague peculiar to thyſelf?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: I cannot tell:
Of this, however, I am well aſſured;
It is a ſource of wretchedneſs to me.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: Were not the thought too bold,
I would deſire to know the cauſe of this.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: If you have not already gueſt it out.
'Twill give me pleaſure to inform you now.
I love to tell the ſtory of my woe,
To vent my ſorrows, and unload my heart;
It ſeems to ſooth my grief, when any one
Will liſten to the undiſſembled tale.
Know then, my huſband is this mighty cauſe;
And 'tis not in the compaſs of my pow'r,
To hide my hatred of the man.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: Thy father ſaid,
Though thou diſlik'dſt his perſon at the firſt,
That time would pour the balm of love,
Into thy mind, and heal the feſtering wound.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: He promis'd, as you ſay; but all in vain.
For three long, tedious years have roll'd away,
And yet I hate him ſtill; yea (what is worſe)
I hate him more and more, at every thought.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: How canſt thou hate ſo excellent a man?
He certainly is kind.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Yes, he is kind enough.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: His perſon and complexion are not bad.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I don't object to him, in that reſpect.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: His fortune is above the reach of want,
Although beneath the aim of envy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I don't complain of that.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: His reputation ſtands as fair,
As yonder cloudleſs ſun, that chears the day.
All ranks of people venerate his name;
The public too of late have honour'd him,
With an appointment to the court of France,
Which he is now preparing to attend—

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: And will, I doubt not, faithfully diſcharge.
I own, I can't diſlike his character:
But there is ſomething in the whole of him,
Diſcordant with the wiſhes of my ſoul.
His paſſions never harmonize with mine.
Some ſecret jarr, I can't tell what, prevails,
To diſconcert the muſic of our lives.
I could eſteem him, as a worthy friend,
An honour'd father, or an uncle dear:
But, as the ſocial partner of my life,
I can't approve of him.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: Softly, good madam, leſt he overhear:
For he is coming in at yonder gate.
Shall I retire?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: You may.

div.stage: Betty retires, and Mr. Jenſon enters.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: What does my dear abroad,
So early in the day?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I watch the progreſs of this pleaſant morn.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: Delightful proſpect! How it fills the mind,
With ſentiments of joyful gratitude!
For every thing conſpires, to give delight.
Dread winter lately bound the earth with ice,—
In howling tempeſts ſwept along our coaſts,
Benumb'll the limbs, and chill'd the thoughts of men,
In ſhort, froze up each genial ſource of joy:
Now breathing ſpring, with milder gales ſucceeds,—
Diſſolves the hoary froſt,—ſpreads o'er the fields
A curious carpet (wrought in nature's loom)
Of chearing green, diverſify'd with flowers;
And bids the year unfold her ſtores to man.
Now night, which wraps one half the earth in gloom
Has roll'd her ſhadows over to the weſt.
Alternate day purſuing night around,
Comes laughing from the eaſt, array'd in light,
Invites the flocks to play, the birds to ſing,
And drowſy mortals to ariſe from ſleep.
Now pleaſure greets the ſoul, through every ſenſe.
Enjoy, my fair, the beauties of the ſpring,
And all the fragrance of the lovely morn:
But I muſt haſten hence, at duty's call.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Why hence, ſo ſoon?

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: To ſettle our affairs,
Before I leave the town: For I muſt ſoon
Embark for France.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Does thy commiſſion ſpecify the time,
When thou muſt fail?

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: No; not the very day.
I wait till Mr. Worthy ſhall arrive,
With my inſtructions from the States.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: How long, before he will return?

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: Sometime this week he is expected back:
Meanwhile I make proviſion for my voyage.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Two years, thou wilt be gone.
And where am I to ſpend theſe two long years?

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: In this, thy native town; or, if thou chooſe,
To prave the dangers of the boiſterous deep,
And viſit Europe's ſhores, thou will be free,
To act according to thy choice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: 'Tis fairly offered. I will ſee my friends,
To take their counſel, in this new affair;
And afterwards inform thee of my choice.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: I can deſire no more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: What ſhall I do? I cannot ſtay behind,
To be the common wonder of the town,
For not attending him. And yet, alas!
I dare not venture on the rolling waves,
And truſt my life to rude, inſulting winds.—
Whom ſhall I ſee, of all my intimates,
To get the beſt advice?—I know not whom—
Oh! Major Shapely—I will ſend for him,
Who from my lover has become my friend;
He keeps his lodgings in the adjoining houſe;
To him I may unboſom all my mind,
And freely reckon o'er my numerous pains:
Though this is but a wretched privilege.
Oh! could I quit the hated name of wife,
Once more to know the joys of ſingle life;
I would not change conditions with a queen,
Or try again the matrimonial ſcene.

div.trailer: The END of the FIRST ACT.

div.head: ACT II.
div.l: I EASILY can gueſs,
Why Lyndall aſks, this interview with me:
For he has been ſo long my humble fool,
Employ'd to carry on my ſecret ſchemes,
Imagining meantime that he and I
Were both purſuing his immediate good,
He's almoſt weary of the endleſs game.
If he ſhould come, as I am ſure he will,
My chief concern will be, to bolſter up
His fainting hopes, and ſeem, if poſſible,
Devoted wholly to his private cauſe;
Since I have no where elſe to go for caſh.
I'll do my beſt. Mr. Lyndall enters.
Well met my friend.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Not very well, I fear. There's nothing well,
Of late, for me. I thought 'twould happen thus;
And yet I blindly followed your advice:
This is the curſe of thoſe, who ſeek applauſe!

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, be calm; and—

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Calm, Sir!
Don't preach up calmneſs any more to me.
I will not hear a word of what you ſay.
Intriguing knave, I have been calm too long;
And loſt my fortune, by the means.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Say rather, thou haſt loſt thy reaſon.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Inſulting charge!
Will you upbraid me then, before my face,
For fooliſhly obeying you?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: My ſoul! Can there be ſuch ingratitude in man!
If my endeavours to promote thy good,
Without the leaſt advantage to myſelf,
Deſerve no better recompence, than this,
(Be witneſs heav'n and earth!) I never more
Will venture in the ſervice of a friend.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: You ought to ſerve your friend,
When you have undertaken.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: It is unwiſe, I find, to undertake;
Since nothing but reproaches are my pay.
By this ungrateful treatment I am taught
An uſeful leſſon for my future life.
Henceforth I'll never patroniſe another's cauſe:
But ſelf ſhall be the pole-ſtar of my aim.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: Be not too raſh, left you repent.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Already I have reaſon to repent,
That I have been ſo much attach'd to thee.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Attach'd to me! Why did you then betray
And diſappoint my expectations?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I never have betray'd
Or diſappointed them

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Did you not promiſe me that place,
Which Mr. Jenſon has obtain'd?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: No farther, Sir, than was within my power.
From motives of unfeigned love to thee,
I undertook indeed on thy behalf,
And urg'd thy ſuit to Mr. Worthy's ear.
Yet, though there ſeem'd a proſpect of ſucceſs,
Our rival juſt obtain'd the prize.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: I wiſh I could have liv'd contented here,
And never entertain'd a thought of fame.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Whence that deſponding wiſh my friend?
Becauſe thou haſt been baffled once,
Wilt thou ſupinely throw aſide thine arms,
And yield thyſelf a priſoner to deſpair?
I ſhould diſdain to have it known, that thou,
For whom I have ſo often baniſh'd ſleep,
To tend the ſolitary lamp of care;
And ſpent whole days of hurry and fatigue;
That thou, dear Sir,—I bluſh to name the thought▪
That thou, alas! wert ſuch a child.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: What can I do, when fortune is my foe?
'Tis downright madneſs to reſiſt our fate.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: 'Tis downright folly to ſubmit to fear:
Be brave, I ſay. Let ſlaves and cowards drudge,
Like reptiles, ſtruggling in the duſt, to crawl
Along the bye-paths of a humble life.
The great and noble walk, with heads erect,
In honour's open road to fame.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: But never find an end.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: That's very true;
The road of honour is without an end.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Ave, that's a great diſcouragement to me:
Why ſhould I run a race, when time and ſtrength
Will never ſuffer me to reach the goal?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: The pleaſure is a ſure and great reward.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: My own expereince gives ſufficient proof
Of your miſtake. Depreſt with dull fatigue,
I curſe the giddy chace.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Thou haſt but juſt ſet out;
And ſtarting always is a painful ſtep,
Though afterwards there's nothing but delight.
Since thou canſt boaſt of an aſpiring ſoul,
I'm ſure, a whole infinity of fame
Will animate thee to purſue the courſe.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Although the thought of glory is ſublime,
My doubts and fears block up the way.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Thoſe obſtacles are only in thyſelf.
Let generous courage once poſſeſs thy breaſt,
And they will vaniſh, like a morning dream:
For courage elevates the towering ſoul,
And builds a bridge o'er every obſtacle
But fear. This bore great ALEXANDER's train,
Upon their march through Aſia's conquered realms,
To his imperial throne, amidſt the ſhouts
Of victory and war. Upon the ſame,
The mighty CAESAR ſtood, and wav'd his flag
Of joy and triumph o'er the trembling world.
And this, e'en now, ſupports a WASHINGTON,
With all the weight of fame, that mortal men
Can heap upon a ſingle character.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: I long to wear the ſhining crown of fame:
But ſtill the toil and danger that attend,
Deter me from the bold attempt.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Wilt thou deſert thy ſtandard firſt thyſelf,
While I, a free auxiliar in thy cauſe,
Suſtain the enterpriſe alone?
Ungrateful wretch! Go, muffle up in ſloth,
And pine away, with indolent deſpair.
Thou fear'ſt "the toil and danger that attend."
Theſe are deſign'd to ſeaſon our delights;
They ſerve as ſauce for milder happineſs;
Without them, we could have no taſte for eaſe,
Or reliſh for enjoyments of the world.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: 'Tis my misfortune—

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I know misfortune is the common lot;
Yet, why complain? We cannot change our ſtate.
Come, enter in the liſt of fame.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Methinks I would,
If I could entertain the fainteſt hopes
Of a commiſſion to the court of France.
Alas! How wild and vain is ſuch a thought!
My rival has ſecur'd it to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: He has poſſeſſion of the poſt, 'tis true;
But may be eaſily remov'd▪

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: How? Is there any proſpect left?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: If I have any judgment to diſcern,
Believe me, Sir, thy proſpect yet is fair.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Pray, let me know the way.
'Twill give me freſh delight, if after all,
My purpoſes be carried to effect.
Do tell me how—I wiſh I may ſuceed;
Yet how I cannot, for my life, conceive.
Say, is he not confirm'd?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: In ſome degree, but may be thence remov'd.
A ſingle chance aſſign'd that place to him;
Another chance may turn him out again.
'Tis eaſy to diſcover ſome miſtake
Sufficient to ſupport a formal charge
Againſt the execution of his truſt;
And having him recall'd, ſtep in thyſelf.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: That will be glorious, if that can be done;
But how ſhall I diſcover this miſtake?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Thou art acquainted with his common life,
Canſt thou not find his private faults?
The beſt of men have ſome unguarded part.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: I am not intimate enough with him,
To trace his ſecret plans. There ſhould be one
Employ'd as ſpy among his family.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Well, Sir, there may be ſuch an one,
For he muſt leave a ſteward of his houſe.
Now find ſome friend, on whom thou canſt rely,
And recommend the ſame to him.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: I have no friend, beſide yourſelf,
To whom I can, with ſafety, truſt my thoughts!
And I am quite aſham'd to trouble you.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Foh! Sir, the trouble is a trifling thing,
When borne by friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: If you will favour me, in this attempt,
I'll amply recompence your pains.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Good Sir, I ſerve thee not for him.
Thou know'ſt I always glory in thy good;
Nor do I cover any recompence:
But only hope to merit thy regard▪
I do no more, dear Sir, than I ſhould wiſh
To have another perſon do for me.
If I had ſuch a cauſe, as thine, at ſtake,
I ſhould undoubtedly deſire the help
Of ſome approved friend.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: Do you engage?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: With all my ſoul, I do.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: I thank you for your friendly zeal;
And will accordingly apply to him.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Don't intimate our aim.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: I'll ſee to that.
My own ſelf-intereſt is too much concern'd,
To ſuffer any want of care from me.
Can I aſſiſt in any other way?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: A thouſand ways.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Name one, the beſt of them;
And let me try my ſkill.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Spread ill reports about the man,
To alienate the people's hearts from him.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: What ill report?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Why, any one,
That is allied to probability.
He is at variance with his wife: Take that;
And repreſent him ſpiritleſs and weak,
Indulging her and under her controul.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: I'll go and try it once.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: My plan ſucceeds. He ſtill remains my dupe.
He'll introduce me to his rival's houſe,
Where I intend indeed to act the ſpy,
But on my own account, inſtead of his,
I mean to carve a portion firſt for me;
And afterwards let others help themſelves.
How?—That's the query—Let me think. [Looks at his watch.] 'Tis time,
For me to wait on Mrs. Jenſon—Well—
I am to pave a way in her eſteem,
To introduce my ſubſequent deſigns.

div.stage: SCENE changes to Mrs. Jenſon's apartment.
Mrs. Jenſon and Maj. Shapely enter.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: With pleaſure, madam, I attend thy call,
And beg to be indulg'd with thy requeſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Firſt, Sir, receive my thanks,
For thy reſpect and friendly complaiſance.
Next pleaſe to favour me with thy advice,
About a place of reſidence for me,
While Mr. Jenſon ſhall be gone to France.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: What place does he appoint?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: He gives me leave to go with him,
Or tarry here in Boſton—as I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Which doſt thou chooſe, to honour Gallia's court;
Or let Boſtonians ſhare thy company?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: I chooſe to hear thy ſentiment.
It is of ſerious conſequence to me;
If therefore thou wilt quit thy compliments,
And counſel me in plain ſincerity,
Thou wilt indulge the wiſhes of a friend.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Upon my word, I mean no compliment▪
But, ſoldier-like, pronounce the ſimple truth.
Thou honour'ſt me, by aſking my advice:
And I ſhould be ungrateful, to deny
The ſmall degree of aid, I can afford.
To what do other friends adviſe?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: I've not apply'd to any body elſe:
For I would rather firſt conſult with thee,
Whom I have ever found to be my friend.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: What I have ever been, I ſtill remain.
So far as confidence may be repos'd
In me, depend on my ſincere re •• rd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Then pray, conſider my important caſe.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: It is a moſt important caſe.
Thy happineſs and life perhaps are hung
Upon the ſingle hinge of one reſolve.
The term of the commiſſion is, I think,
About two years.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Preciſely two.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: The trouble of a voyage is great;
To tarry here, will alſo give thee pain:
Theſe inconveniencies thou muſt expect—

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: See! Mr Jenſon comes.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: [Aſide.] (I muſt, of conſequence, retire,
Some other way, that I may ſhun his ſight.)
I'll viſit thee another time.

div.stage: [Maj. Shapely goes out at one door, and Mr. Jenſon comes in at another.]

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: Haſt thou determin'd yet,
Reſpecting the propoſals, that I made.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Not fully, Sir. I have not yet had time,
To weigh the probable events of both.
Hard is my lot, and always will be hard!

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: That fooliſh thought will make it harder ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Ungenerous man! What, may I not complain?
I muſt and will, in ſpite of thee.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: Complaint will only aggravate thy grief.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Well, let it aggravate, I bear it all;
And 'tis the only comfort of my life,
Whatever it may ſeem to thee.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: A wretched comfort, I ſhould think.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: 'Tis all I have, as wretched as it is.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: My dear, this does no good.
We muſt endure the ills, we can't remove.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: That is the cauſe of my complaint.
If I could ſhake theſe evils off, be ſure,
I would not ſtand, and peeviſhly complain▪
But I am burdened, with a weight of woe,
Which, like a mountain, ſinks me down to grief.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: What wouldſt thou have me do, for thee?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: For me?

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: For thee, my love.
Declare thy wiſh; and ſwift as paſſing winds,
I'll haſte to ſee the thing perform'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I have no wiſh.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: Reſpecting any thing, I care not what;
But ſpeak thy pleaſure; and it ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I have no ſpecial wiſh, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: Who ſhall be left in charge with our accounts?
Come, tell me, who?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Some honeſt man;
Juſt whom thou pleaſeſt to appoint.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: Oh! Don't refuſe thy choice.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: Good day, my friend!

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: A happy day to thee. I am inform'd,
Thou art about to leave America,
For Europe's famous climes.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: Thy information ſpeaks the truth.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: And who will have the management
Of thy domeſtic cares?

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: No perſon is engaged.
If there is any one, whom thou haſt try'd,
And prov'd to be an honeſt, ſkilful man,
Be good enough, to mention him.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: There's Major Shapely, Sir,

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: I have already thought of him.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Him I can recommend,
As one, who is acquainted with the world;
And I have found him an unfailing friend,
A perſon of fidelity and truſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I always thought the ſame of him.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: Would he be willing to engage?

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: Yes, I believe he would.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: What doſt thou think of him, my dear?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I don't object to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: I'll ſee the gentleman,
And offer him the truſt.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: Shall I acquaint him, Sir, with thy deſires?

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: Do, Sir, with compliments from me;
And let us know his mind.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Perhaps he'll be diſpos'd to come himſelf,
And let thee know.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: I ſhall be glad to wait upon him here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I hope he will accept.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: By that I judge,
Thou haſt determined to remain at home.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: I've not determined either way;
But now revolve the matter in my mind.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: Do let me urge thee to conclude.
Our time is ſhort, and calls for quick diſpatch.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Permit me, therefore, to retire,
For more convenient exerciſe of thought.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: Go, with my wiſhes for thy good.
She is exceedingly diſturb'd.
Thou'rt welcome, Major Shapely, to my houſe,
And more than welcome, if thou wilt comply
With my requeſt, by Mr. Lyndall's hand.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: I readily comply.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: A generous recompence awaits thy care,
Together with a title to my thanks.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: How ſoon ſhall I be needed here?

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: Immediately.
I'll give thee my accounts, this very hour.
Excuſe me, Sir; I'll ſoon return.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Proceed according to thy wiſh.
Now every thing is coming right again.
I've gain'd admiſſion to his houſe and heart.
'Twill not be hard to raiſe a civil war
Between this ill-match'd pair; which muſt be done.
I've ſworn their final ruin, ever ſince
Her father gave her to his rival arms.
I can't endure the thought of my repulſe;
It ſpurs my ſpirits on, to ſeek revenge.
Thus far, I have ſucceeded pretty well:
He thinks me honeſt, faithful and diſcreet;
And ſhe believes me her unſhaken friend.
GOD knows, I am, at heart, a friend to none
On earth, except my own beloved ſelf.
Who does not love himſelf, and his concerns?
Let me conſider—How ſhall I proceed?—
The place of her abode is not agreed upon—
That is the plan—There's room enough for ill.
That little bubble, trifling as it ſeems,
Shall be fermented to a bluſtering ſtorm.
This day, ſhe has ſolicited my aid.
I felt the throbing pulſe of her deſign,
And learnt from thence her mental ſtate of health.
I'm next to give a potion of advice,
In which I can diſſolve an amorous pill,
And mix a little ſweetening flattery,
To make it ſuit the palate of her pride.
Thus, in compliance with my ſecret will,
I am prepar'd with inſtruments for ill.
If fortune kindly favour my deſign,
The lovely Jenſon may at length be mine.

div.trailer: The END of the SECOND ACT.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: IN conſequence of thy command,
I have procur'd thoſe articles.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: 'Tis well; and where are they depoſited?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: In ſtore, all ready to be put on board.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: The preparation for my voyage ſucceeds,
According to my wiſh. Did nothing elſe
Retard my progreſs, or perplex my mind,
I ſhould be ſoon in readineſs to ſail.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: What is there elſe?
Does any obſtacle impede thy way?

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: The circumſtances of my family
Affect my ſoul, with great uneaſineſs,
And quite embarraſs my deſigns.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Thou art afraid, to leave them here with me:
I know, I have not merited the truſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: No; that is not the ground of my concern.
If Mrs. Jenſon would declare her choice,
Either to go with me, or tarry here,
I might prepare accordingly for her:
But it diſturbs and diſconcerts my ſchemes,
To be in doubt, reſpecting that affair.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Haſt thou then offer'd her a choice;

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: I have; and beg'd of her to chooſe.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Sure, that was fair.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: And yet ſhe utterly declines.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Perhaps ſhe has not yet had time enough,
To form a prudent choice.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: She aſks no longer time;
But ſeems determin'd not to chooſe at all.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: What reaſon does ſhe urge,
To juſtify, or rather to excuſe,
Her unaccountable behaviour?

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: Inſtead of juſtifying it,
She is forever muttering out complaints,
Of her unhappy life.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: She can't blame thee, for that which heav'n ordains.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: She does; however ſtrange it may appear.
And calls me the deſtroyer of her bliſs.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Oh ſhocking! Canſt thou bear it all?
The ſenſeleſs, ſtupid creature well deſerves
To be deſpis'd by all the human race.
Condemn a tender huſband, for the leave
Of chooſing for herſelf—then add complaints!

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: I'm nearly weary of her, I confeſs.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Nearly weary of her! 'Tis enough
To blaſt the patience of another Job.
I wonder thou endureſt her, a day.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: Alas! I am inur'd to her camplaints.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Inur'd to them! I am amaz'd.
She has been long complaining, I perceive.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: Inceſſantly, ſince firſt we join'd our hands.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Indeed! It ſeems impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: It is the truth.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I doubt it not. Pray, pardon me.
I don't diſpute the truth of what thou ſay'ſt,
Though this, at firſt, appears incredible.
How can'ſt thou live with her? A fine help-meet,
As ever walk'd, ſince Eve involv'd the world
In guilt, and miſery and cruel death!

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: Oh I'm the moſt unhappy man on earth.
My life is nothing but a ſcene of woe.
Whenever I approach, her fore-head low'rs,
With ſullen ſcowls, as hideous as the grave.
And then her tongue—Oh! Who can calmly ſit
Beneath a woman's ſcolding tongue?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: No man of ſenſe and ſentiment:
For nature is abus'd, when ladies ſcold.
Let men, upon occaſion, fret and rage;
Their natural roughneſs gives them ſome excuſe:
But angry paſſions miſbecome the fair,
Compos'd throughout of nature's fineſt parts;
Whoſe lovely forms are beauty's maſter-piece;
Whoſe features are an emblem of the ſex,
And ſhow the proper temper of their mind.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: No more, dear Sir. no more!
I know the force of female exellence;
Not leſs I know their follies and their faults;
For Mrs. Jenſon is the ſum of all,
A true epitome of woman kind.
Her charm 〈◊〉 univerſal and complete:
But Vaſhti-like, ſhe muſt be ſtill ador'd,
Or elſe—farewell to all domeſtic peace!
For ſhe will ſet the keeneſt edge of ſpleen
Upon the adverſe incidents of life,
And change a paradiſe of ſocial joy,
Into a hell of bickering and rage.
How often have I wiſh'd the gordian knot
Of matrimony were again untied!

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I wonder other people have not heard
Of your domeſtic ſtrife.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: They have;
I am become a proverb in the ſtreets.
I heard a man obſerving to his friend,
"'Tis baſe for one of Mr. Jenſon's rank,
"To be ſo tamely govern'd by his wife."

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: My ſorrow! has it come to this?

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: To this, it has.
His words were ſharper than a two-edg'd ſword;
I feel them ſtill; they pierc'd my fooliſh heart,
And left a ſting behind.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: So I believe. I wiſh that were the end:
But thou muſt rule thy houſe, or (mark my word)
The ruin of thy public character
Will be as ſure, as death.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: How rule my houſe?
I've us'd uncommon lenity with her,
In all our intercourſe.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: That ſeems to be reaſon of her ſcorn;
Thou waſt in fault. 'Twas beſt to be ſevere.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: I hop'd to win her by indulgent means.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: The conſequence too ſadly proves,
That ſuch indulgence only tempted her,
To run a greater length of wilfulneſs.
Thy kind civility encreas'd her pride,
As cultivation helps a weed to grow.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: I wiſh, I had begun to uſe the curb,
Before her pride had gain'd maturity.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: It is not yet too late.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: How may her ſtubborn ſoul be ſway'd?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: How? There's no difficulty, in the caſe:
For woman is as weak as proud.
Pride has its origin in impotence.
Apply a little oppoſition to her will;
And, though her rage may bluſter up a while,
The ſtorm will very ſoon ſubſide.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: Doſt thou imagine ſhe may thus be rul'd,
By gentle exerciſe of government?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Perhaps her ſtubbornneſs has grown ſo ſtrong,
As to require a little longer time,
Or harder trial of authority;
However ſhe will gladly yield.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: I am almoſt perſuaded to attempt
Her ſubjugation:—But I hate the taſk.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: It will be worſe, if longer left undone.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Nay more, it will become impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: I know it will, in time.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Beſides, a lucky opportunity
Invites thee to begin, without delay.
Her backwardneſs to pitch upon a place
Of reſidence, affords a fair pretence.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: A happy opportunity enough.
If I begin with her, I ſhall have need
Of thy aſſiſtance and advice.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: My ſelf and ſervice are at thy command.
But don't let her, by any means, ſuſpect,
That any body is concern'd with thee;
She ought to think the undertaking thine.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: She ought, indeed, and ſhall I am reſolv'd,
To hazard one experiment. Mr. Jeaſon goes out.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: How much more eaſy 'tis,
To raiſe diſſention, than to ſettle peace!
The ſeeds of diſcord are ſo deeply ſown,
In every corner of the human heart,
A little culture maturates their growth,
And preſently the bitter fruits appear.
Such is the caſe of this unhappy match.
A houſe divided ſo againſt itſelf,
Moſt ſurely cannot ſtand. Then let it fall.
What need I care? It will not fall on me.
Yet what a wretch I am, to triumph thus,
In the misfortunes of my fellow men!
'Tis truly deviliſh; I confeſs, it is.
I would not undertake it for the world,
Unleſs it were, to benefit myſelf.
Oh! no; I don't wiſh any harm to them.
Well, well; I'll think of this another time.
At preſent I muſt proſecute my plan,
Which, I perceive, begins to operate.
Her ſpirits are ſublime, and ſcorn reſtraint,
Which he has undertaken to impoſe;
They'll blaze, as quick as powder touch'd with fire.
Hah! Lyndall? Yes—I welcome thee again.
Thy preſence always gives me joy.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: Your complaiſance demands my thanks.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: How does thy courage ſtand to-day?

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: Faith! 'tis but juſt above the freezing point.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: It has been quite below.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: And will be there again,
For any thing I ſee, to keep it up.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Come, come, no more of that. Thou art a man.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: I humbly hope to be eſteem'd a man.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Then act according to that character,
And leave the ſpleen to whimſical old maids.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: I ſcorn a ſplenetic deſpondency,
As much as you, or any other man:
And notwithſtanding all, I dread—

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Aye, that's the very thing, that will
Unwind the whole contrivance of thy cauſe.
Thou dread'ſt the trouble of the enterprize,
Though I endure the greateſt ſhare.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: You cenſure me too ſoon.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Forgive my fault; it is th' effect of love
Sometimes, I own, my zeal to honour thee
Induces me to unbecoming 〈◊〉 :
But, if ſincerity has any worth.
Thou wilt not judge the leſs, but 〈◊〉 thy friend.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Your friendſhip is the 〈◊〉 of my hopes,
And has, as it deſerves, my hearty thanks.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: My wiſhes claim no more.
This approbation is a full reward
For all my care of thy important cauſe.
And as I would in future merit it,
Permit me to renew my ſacred truſt.
[Kneels] Upon the honour of a Gentleman,
Upon a Chriſtian's everlaſting faith,
And on the credit of a Soldier's word,
(Let heaven be witneſs to this ſolemn oath!)
My hands, my head and heart ſhall all be thine.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Amidſt the numerous evils of my life,
My diſappointments, loſſes and defeats,
(Thanks to the ſtar, that rul'd my natal hour!)
I have a friend, in whom I can confide.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Thy confidence hath fan'd the ſpark of love,
That warm'd, before, the centre of my heart.
An ardour of benevolence will ſpread,
Through all the future actions of my life.
In any office, thou may'ſt now command
The wiſhes and endeavours of thy friend.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: The office, which you now ſuſtain,
At preſent wholly occupies my mind.
But, I'm afraid you never will ſucceed.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: On what foundation doſt thou build thy fear?

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: Upon my former diſappointments.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: This fear of thine denotes a prudent mind,
And proves its author provident and wiſe;
But (truſt a friend) it has no ſolid ground.
Thou haſt been diſappointed, I allow;
Which circumſtance ſhould not diſhearten thee▪
For numerous thouſands of the human kind,
Beneath ſome ſudden ſhock of adverſe fate,
Has trembled, with a momentary fear,
Which only rous'd their native fortitude,
To perſevere, and finally ſucceed.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: With your aſſiſtance, I will perſevere,
E'en let the conſequence be what it may.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: 'Tis nobly ſaid. Thou reaſoneſt like a man.
Thy brave reſolve, at leaſt, deſerves ſucceſs;
It will ſupport my ſpirits, while I ſtrive,
To learn the movements of thy rival's ſchemes.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Since you are now admitted to his houſe,
I hope there will be ſome diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Moſt probably there will:
For I have frequent opportunities
Of joining freely in diſcourſe with him.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: When was the laſt?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: An hour is not elaps'd, ſince he was here.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: And when will be the next?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I judg'd by what he ſaid,
He would return, before this time.
I narrowly obſerve his common talk,
From which I truſt to gain his thoughts.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: Is not that perſon he, who walks this way?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Yes; that is he.
I'll found him with my utmoſt ſkill:
Do thou go out of ſight a little while,
'Till he ſhall have perform'd his buſineſs here,
And then ſtep in again.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: I'll do as you adviſe.

div.stage: Mr. Lyndall retires, and Mr. Jenſon enters.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: So ſoon return'd! Well! How does diſcipline
Appear to ſuit her ladyſhip?

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: Suit? Bleſs my ſtars!
She ſcolded, ſtorm'd and thunder'd out her threats,
As if ſhe meant to cruſh the univerſe,
About my ears.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Such conduct is, by no means, ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: I find it operates,
According to thy prophecy.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: She will undoubtedly be worſe awhile▪
For government; the ſtubborn always are.
'Tis well thou haſt begun to conquer her,
Before her temper is too obſtinate
To bend to any rule.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: It is a task.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Aye, that is true, it is indeed a taſk.
Her folly renders it a needful one,
In order for a quiet life.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: A quiet life is all I have in view.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: A motive worthy of a gentleman!
Thy manly reſolution is too great
To quit this neceſſary diſcipline,
Without accompliſhing the end.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: I will endeavour to proceed.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: To yield would be unſafe;
Becauſe 'twould give a ſanction to her pride.
Nor wilt thou think it wiſe to ſlack the rein;
Leſt ſhe acquire new ſtrength by thy delay.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: How may I beſt prevent her inſolence,
And bring the matter to a ſpeedy cloſe?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: By ſetting every thing againſt her will.
If ſhe has any ornament of worth,
It may be wreſted from her, if thou pleaſe,
To teach her due ſubmiſſion to her lord.
But my affection caries me too far:
I ought to know my place, and not adviſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: Let me reflect—what can I take away?
She wears a diamond necklace.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: A happy circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: She has my picture too in miniature.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Well, that's more lucky ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: I'll ſieze upon them both.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Do this at different times,
'Twould tend perhaps to mortify her pride,
If thou ſhould'ſt ſeemingly intend to ſell,
Or give away thoſe things.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: I like the plan; ſhe muſt and ſhall ſubmit.
Meanwhile my other neceſſary cares
Demand me firſt another way. [Mr. Jenſon goes out]

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: To be depriv'd of all her ornaments,
Will cut her tender feelings to the quick;
And then will be my time to win her heart.
This is a project, that will never fail,
If I can open Lyndall's purſe again.
The fool, I ſee, is coming in. Mr. Lyndall enters.
I heartily rejoice with thee, my friend.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: The noble proſpect that unfolds to view,
Reſpecting thy affairs.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: What now? Have you diſcover'd any thing.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I have perform'd a grand diſcovery,
Which makes my heart exult for joy
Within the progreſs of a few more months,
I hope, dear ſir (if nothing interfere)
To ſee thee mounted on a prince's ſeat,
Diſpenſing orders to ſubmiſſive crowds.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: A prince's ſeat! What, I a prince?
You rally me, I doubt.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Let me be call'd a fool and knave,
Or (what is worſe) a coward, through the world;
Nay, let my tongue become a hiffing ſnake,
My head make food for dogs and filthy crows,
And Shapely be a term of infamy,
If this be not my real ſentiment.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: A prince? How grand the ſound of prince?
Then you ſhall be the next in dignity.
I'll not forget your kindneſs; no, not I:
For that would ill-become a generous prince.
I am ſurpris'd.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Not more than I. It is thy juſt deſert.
Since thou haſt ſown the ſeeds of induſtry,
Now reap an ample harveſt of renown.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: My ſoul ſtands tip-toe at the thought:

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: My friends will ſhout, huzza! for joy;
And thou (however modeſty may bluſh)
Ev'n thou wilt feel a ſecret joy, to wield
The ſword of Juſtice over guilty heads;
To poize the doubtful ſcale of Equity,
And hold out Mercy's ſceptre in thy hand,
With pardon for the poor and penitent.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Who could have thought it? You ſhall be my friend
I'll grant you any thing you aſk,
I'll obtain ſucceſs. Do tell me all,
That I may hang no longer in ſuſpence.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I muſt be very brief.
Among the incidents of our diſcourſe,
I fortunately found a ſecret way,
That led me to the very cabinet
Of his deſigns; where I have form'd a ſcheme,
To take his conduct in a fatal ſnare.
I have not leiſure to relate the whole.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: O wondrous man!
I wiſh I could contrive like you.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Be reſolute and bravely perſevere;
For that's the only method to be great.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: I will be reſolute. Away, my fears,
Be gone; I've no more uſe for you.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I honour thy intent.
And I have need of perſevering zeal:
For there is yet ſome difficulty.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: Not great, I would believe.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Not very great.
'Tis this; I can't, at once, diſcharge my truſt,
As manager of Mr. Jenſon's houſe
(Which muſt be done, or I ſhall be diſmiſs'd)
And execute this plan of mine.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Where ſhall we find a deputy.
I'm confident ſome perſon may be found;
Nay ſhall be found, and that this afternoon.—
It is not prudent, I ſuppoſe, for me,
To be immediately concern'd.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: By no means, leſt our purpoſe be reveal'd.
There is a friend of mine, who may be gain'd,
For ſuitable reward.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Engage him, Sir; and I will pay his price.
Here, take this purſe of gold.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: A generous ſum!

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: If neceſſary, you may draw for more.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: There poſſibly may be a call for more;
But this, at preſent, is enough.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: Take what is beſt; but let it not be known.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Aye, that is well obſerv'd.
The ſecret muſt be kept, and well thou know'ſt,
A ſecret is a dangerous, ſlippery thing:
Juſt like a priſoner immur'd in goal,
It peaks through bluſhing cheeks and conſcious eyes,
As through the windows of a priſon hall;
And if the tongue but juſt unlock the door,
Away the ſecret glides, as quick as light,
And can no more be caught. Be cautious then,
To hold the ſecret in thy breaſt.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: All neceſſary caution ſhall be us'd,
So far as my ability extends.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I have no doubt of it.
If thou wilt nobly ſcorn unmanly fear,
The object of thy wiſhes will appear:
Fame's loudeſt trumpet will declare thy name,
And liſtening rumour echo back to fame.

div.trailer: The END of the THIRD ACT.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: I NEVER entertain'd
The moſt exalted ſentiments of him:
But this abuſe has quite aſtoniſh'd me.
He has deſtroy'd my happineſs.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: With what pretence?
There is ſome motive, that induces him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: To make me wretched, ſeems his only aim.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: It cannot be. The moſt abandon'd wretch,
Who ever brought diſgrace upon mankind,
Ne'er wiſh'd to wrong a virtuous character,
For nothing, but the ſake of doing wrong.
He doubtleſs has ſome ſecret views.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I can't imagine what.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Nor I. His conduct is a paradox to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: I ſhudder at th' event.
Could I be ſet at liberty from him—
Yet, Oh! my wiſhes are compleatly vain.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Four years ago thou didſt not think of this;
Then merit ſeem'd to have a juſt reward;
Amanda's name was full in every mouth.
Whenever thou waſt pleas'd to walk abroad,
Both young and old roſe up and bow'd to thee.
At every window, ſtood the ſparkling beans,
And rival beauties ſtole an envious glance.
Youth, love and chearfulneſs compoſ'd thy train;
Fame ran before, the herald of thy ſteps;
Pale envy gaz'd, and ſigh'd, then ſhut her eyes;
While malice ſhook her head, and turn'd away,
At thy approach.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: O ſpare me, ſpare me, Sir:
Nor urge my feelings, with ſo keen a ſting.
I was Amanda blooming, fair and gay.
Extolling youth and talkative old-age
Fed me with praiſe, until it made me ſick.
Poor fooliſh girl! I fondly thought that life
Would always flow in ſuch a gentle ſtream.
But, ah! Amanda is no more my name;
Nor this the greateſt change, that I ſuſtain.
I ſcarcely know myſelf.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Thy change is great.
I'd freely ſpend my life, on thy account,
To turn the wheel of fortune back again.

sp.speaker: Mrs, J,
sp.p: I'm wrong'd, neglected and deſpis'd.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I feel thy wrongs,
And heartily condole with thee.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J,
sp.p: I am undone, alas! I am undone.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Oh! Don't dear lady, don't lament.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Did thou, one moment, feel, what I endure,
The hidden pain, that rankles in this breaſt—
Thou wouldſt not chide my tears. Thy heart would melt.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: I pity thee with all my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Ah! wretched me!
The poor remains of what Amanda was!
Where are my charms, my once-admired charms?
Where have my friends and fawning lovers fled?
Farewell, my ſchemes of love and happineſs!
And ye, my lovers and my friends, farewell!
I give you back your broken promiſes.
Farewell the amorous glance, and humble bow!
Adieu to chearing ſongs, to feſtive mirth,
To ſocial ſmiles, that ſpread from face to face,
To viſits, gay aſſemblies, brilliant balls,
And all the glory of the world, adieu!
I take my mournful leave of thee, O world;
Thy beauty's faded; thy delights are cold:
Farewell, farewell, thou empty, flattering world!
Begone, with all thy fair, inviting ſcenes!
Farewell, contented thoughts, and quiet reſt!
And, did not fear forbid the tragic deed,
I'd bid a long, a laſt adieu to life.
But nature ſhrinks, and cries, forbear.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Obey her kind command.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: For what intent?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: To live.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: To bear this tedious load of miſery.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: If borne with fortitude,
It may, perhaps, grow leſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: But that's improbable.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: I hope not quite.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: It is, and more;
'Tis utterly impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: I own thy proſpect is ſomewhat obſcur'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: 'Tis darker than Egyptian night.
My ills encreaſe with every cloſing day;
No one can tell me what will be their end.
A ſecret dread of ſomething yet reſerv'd,
Behind the curtain of myſterious fate,
Reproves my reſtleſs thoughts, for looking back.
O for ſome prophet's fate-unfolding hand,
To draw aſide the intervening veil,
That I might peep into the unſeen world,
And view the ſecrets of futurity!
O blind futurity! diſcloſe thy ſcenes,
To let me ſee my fate!

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: It might not be ſo well, to know thy fate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: 'Tis poſſible; but yet I want to know.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: As much of it depends
On Mr. Jenſon's life, examine him;
Survey his actions, with a cautious eye:
Theſe cannot fail to intimate his thoughts,
Let them be good or bad. But think than good.
A man muſt not be ſentenc'd for a crime
(Eſpecially ſo black a crime at this)
Without ſufficient evidence of guilt.
Eſteem him honeſt, as I hope he is;
And be inclin'd to find him free from blame:
For otherwiſe, a life of wretchedneſs
Will be thy certain lot. Pray think of that.
I don't believe he can be ſuch a wretch,
As thy ſuſpicion prophecies of him;
He knows thy worth and loves thy charms too well.
But ſatisfy thyſelf, and doubt no more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Thou ſpeakeſt wiſely, for my good.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I ſpeak the language of ſincerity.
This is my beſt advice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: I'm bound to love and thank thee, for thy zeal.
I'll watch him, every moment, night and day.
Wilt thou be kind enough do the ſame?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: At thy deſire, I will. It is my joy,
To aid the virtuous ſtruggling in diſtreſs.
However, this muſt be conceal'd from him,
Or I ſhall not be able to aſſiſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: It ſhall not reach the notice of his eyes.
Or ears, or ev'n his thoughts from me.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I beg to take my leave of thee;
For buſineſs calls.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: How complaiſant this Major Shapely is!
His company is like the riſing ſun;
It drives away the tedious night of grief.
He is a moſt accompliſhed gentleman,
Deſign'd no doubt, to bleſs ſome happy bride.
I wiſh to Heav'n, that I might be the one!
Yet fortune always mocks my, fruitleſs wiſh:
Accurſed fortune, that deſtroy'd my hopes,
And bound me to the only man, I hate.
O cruel huſband! O unfeeling man!
Can he, with pleaſure, ſport at my diſtreſs?
The Major doubts has ſame ſecret view.
What ſecret view? No other view than baſe—
'Tis ſo—Vile wretch!—The Major ſeems alarm'd—
Some ſcandalous deſign to ruin me!
Why did I not miſtruſt his crime before!
We never liv'd in love, like man and wife;
Nor did we marry, for the ſake of love.
'Tis plain, he meant to be a plague to me.
Thank fortune, Major Shapely is my friend!—
Deceitful villain! break his marriage vows?
Yield his affection to a proſtitute?
Juſt Heav'n heap curſes on the wretch's head,
And blaſt his name! Perfidious man!
If this be true, his death will not avail,
To ſatisfy my angry appetite.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Thou haſt return'd with ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I'm here and there and every where,
As neceſſary buſineſs urges me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Doſt thou believe, that he is true?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Mr. Jenſon,

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: That he is true?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Aye, true to wedlock.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Why, yes; I hope he is.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Hope! So do I; but doſt thou think he is?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Sometimes I do. I've many thoughts of him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Do ſpeak thy ſentiments.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I dare not: If I ſhould,
They would not ſatisfy thy mind.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I muſt be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Then mark him, and his talk.
If he be falſe 'twill certainly appear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I will obſerve him, with the utmoſt care.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: She'll find him falſe enough, I warrant her.
Her jealous mind is happily prepar'd,
For him to take away her furniture.
Faith! this will work: And ſo will Lyndall's fright.
I love to ſwell him up, with airy thoughts,
And, by the alternate help of hope and fear,
To blow the bubble round to any point,
Where either intereſt or my ſport directs.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: I ſay, I ſhall be ruin'd after all.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Don't be a child,
Becauſe a little danger threatens us.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: He will diſcover us, we may be ſure;
We cant prevent it, by the beſt of means:
But notwithſtanding all your promiſes,
I ſhall be brought to puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: My ſafety is embark'd with thine;
I cant eſcape the ſtorm, that ſhipwrecks thee.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Aye, you are right, I don't complain of you.
I have almoſt a mind, to run away,
Or move into the country, and forget
I ever ſtood a candidate for fame;
There is ſo much uncertainty!

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Uncertainty!
That ought to warm thy diligence,
Inſtead of freezing up thy active zeal.
I grant that honour is uncertain; ſo is life.
Thou doſt not ceaſe, however, to provide,
For days, for weeks, and months and years to come.
I pray thee, be conſiſtent with thyſelf;
Perform thy part, and let the event alone.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: I muſt acknowledge that is beſt.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: It is not only beſt, but ſafeſt too:
For cowardice unhinges all our ſtrength;
It makes the fancy eaſily tranſform
A mole-hill trifle to a mountain toil;
It bids us flee for life when none purſues,
And hide from danger right in danger's way,
Then cry, to let our hiding place be known.
Be brave, be manly and thou wilt be great.
What need of fear?

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.p: Becauſe he views me with ſuſpicious eyes.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: 'Tis not impoſſible to ſhut the eyes
Of his ſuſpicion, cloſe as ſolid gold.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Then I ſhall feel ſecure.
O bleſt ſecurity!

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Although 'tis poſſible,
It will create expence.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: I value not expence, to make me ſafe.
I would not have another fright, like this,
For all the gold and ſilver of Peru.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Aye, ſafety is to be prefer'd to gold.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: But how ſhall I diſpoſe of one,
To make the other ſure?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: The way is plain:
For gold does any thing, and every thing;
It makes the Lawyer plead, the Parſon preach,
The Merchant trade, the Doctor tend the ſick,
And Politicians oil the wheels of ſtate:
For this, the Servant waits, the Soldier fights,
The Father ſweats, to turn the rugged glebe,
Mechanics toil, and Sailors tempt the ſeas.
This fills the hungry mouth with drink and meat,
And clothes the ſhivering back againſt the cold—
Nay, money anſwers all demands, but death;
And therefore cannot fail to make us ſafe.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: The conſequence is fairly drawn—
I don't know what to do, or how to turn.
The profits of my trade are all conſum'd.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Thy caſh is lent on loan,
And will return, with intereſt ten per cent.

sp.speaker: Lynd.
sp.l: Well, I ſhall make or break. I'll fell my ſtock,
And keep it all for read uſe. Mr. Lyndall goes out.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I can't but laugh, to think how I 〈◊〉 rais'd
This fellow's expectations, ſtep by ſtep,
Upon the ladder of an empty fame,
So high above his real character,
The giddy proſpect fairly turns his head.
I have his fortune at my own command,
And that is all I wiſh.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: I hope I don't diſturb you, Major Shapel •

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: No, Betty, not at all. [Writing]
Well, how do family affairs go on?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: Why, Mr. Jenſon and his lady are 〈◊〉 talk,
Concerning their intended voyage.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Your miſtreſs, I obſerve,
Is very ſorrowful of late.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I know ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Extremely ſorrowful—I pity her:
For ſhe deſerves a more propitious fate.
She is the ſweeteſt flower of all her ſex,
And fit to match with any emperor.
I'd freely riſk my life, to give her peace;
And think her favour a ſufficient pay.
It ſeems impoſſible for any man,
Although his heart were made of ſolid flint,
To be regardleſs of her excellence.—
I muſt be gone, a minute, to the ſtore. goes out.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I'll tell my miſtreſs, what he ſays of her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I ſhall not go to France.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I'm glad of that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Where is the Major?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: Stept over to the ſtore. He will rejoice—

sp.speaker: Mrs J.
sp.p: He'll ſoon return, I truſt.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: Yes, very ſoon.
The Major pities thee, as much as I,
And ſpeaks of thee, with rapture and concern.
Look! There he comes. I leave thee.

div.stage: Maj. Shapely enters, and Betty retires.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Thy fears,
Reſpecting Mr. Jenſon's baſe deſign,
Have prov'd too true.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: What evidence appears?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: He's robb'd me of my property.
He gave me (juſt before our wedding day)
A diamond neck-lace: This he has re ••• m'd.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: I was convinc'd he would betray himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: It was an ornament,
For which I had a ſingular regard.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: He has ſome other uſe for it.
Alas! It is a melancholy truth,
That huſbands ſhould deſcend to ſuch abuſe:
For, look through nature's various family,
In every rank, beneath the human race,
The males as much excell the other half,
In beauty, as in ſtrength; and yet are kind.
The ſocial Dove conſoles his partner's care;
The Swallow feeds and tends and chears his mate;
The Robbin watches o'er his ſweeting's life,
Affording her protection and ſupport;
And ev'ry one, according to his kind,
Acknowledges and honours nature's law:
But the reverſe obtains among mankind:
Here beauty crowns the female ſex alone;
Yet faithleſs men—How painful is the thought!—
Yet men are faithleſs, changing and unkind:
Thy huſband is a witneſs to this truth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Deteſted wretch! He ought to looſe his head.
I priz'd the lace too highly, I believe;
And I ſhall never have another.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Yes, I have one, which ſhall be thine,
If that can ſatisfy thy loſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Thou art extremely kind.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: With thy permiſſion, I will go▪
And bring it here to thee.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: I have no reaſon to object.
Good God! How kind! It makes me curſe my fate.
I wiſh I could invent ſome happy way,
To baniſh Mr. Jenſon from my ſight,
And let this courteous Major take his place.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Take this ſmall preſent, as a pledge
Of my reſpect.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I thank thee from my heart.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Were all the univerſe within my power,
It ſhould be freely thine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Words can't expreſs my gratitude.
A lovely neck-lace, rich and elegant!

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: On thy account,
I wiſh it worth a golden world.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: It is at much ſuperior to the one,
My huſband lately robb'd me of, as that
Was better than a ſtring of beads.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: 'Twas robbery indeed, or ſomething worſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: What worſe?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Aye, that's the myſtery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: It is no myſtery to me.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: It is, in ſome degree, reveal'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: 'Tis plain enough; I want no ſtronger proof.
Revenge alone—

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Hark! Somebody is coming in.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: No doubt 'tis he.
I would much rather ſee a ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: I'll go aſide.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Do ſtep into the cloſet there;
And take the key, to be ſecure.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: I will obey.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: He brings ſome inſult, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Take notice. He may throw ſome further light
Upon his dark deſign.

div.stage: Maj. Shapely goes into the cloſet, and Mr. Jenſon enters.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: Since thou diſdain'ſt my company,
In violation of our nuptial oath,
Reſtore my picture back to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Moſt readily [Giving it to him] I would not have it here.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: Some other perſon may eſteem it more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Some other perſon! Oh! I'll be his death,
Or die myſelf. [Maj. Shapely re-enters.] Did'ſt thou obſerve?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Obſerve! The ſecret's out,
As plain as open day.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: The wretch ſhall die.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: He merits death.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: A hundred deaths, he does.
Prove falſe himſelf! Then lay that charge on me
Deſtruction ſmite him dead, upon the ſpot!

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: 'Tis villainous.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: 'Tis worſe, a thouſand times.
A common villain is a ſaint to him.
Oh, what a monſter of iniquity!
Prove falſe to wedlock! Curſed child of guilt,
Some lewd infernal, ſhap'd in human guiſe,
To bring diſgrace upon mankind and me!

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: I am aſham'd to own him as a man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: A villain, falſe as Beelzebub!
Charge me with violation of my oath!

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: His conduct is a ſtriking teſt of guilt:
He could not harbour ſuch a thought of thee,
Unleſs it were familiar to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: God knows that North is not ſo far from South,
As ſuch a purpoſe from my heart;
Yet he, a monſter, throws his crime on me,
And plunders me, to deck a proſtitute—
Some other perſon—fit for him, I hope—
A ſcolding fury, ugly as the grave,
As croſs as death, and black as his deſires;
And ſhe, forſooth! muſt have my ornaments.
Let them be ſnakes and vipers in her hands,
To poiſon her and him! O perjur'd wretch!
He has debas'd himſelf, to injure me.
Deſpiſe him, curſe him, help me kill the knave,
And bury him a mile within the earth,
Or ſink him to the bottom of the ſea.
O that I were a man! He ſhould not live
Another day: This night ſhould be his laſt.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Shall I be executioner for thee?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Yes; ſeize the villain, while his crime is warm,
And hang him, burn him, drown him—any thing,
So matter what; but ſtop his guilty breath.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: At thy command, I'll take away his life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Quick let him die. He's wrong'd and ruin'd me.
He never had a ſingle ſpark of love:
I thought he never had, and now tis plain.
Why did I marry him againſt my choice?
I was a fool, a ſilly, thoughtleſs fool;
My cruel father too—But he is gone,
And all are gone: I've not a friend on earth.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Yes, I'm thy friend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Heav'n be thy recompence!
Befriend me ſtill. My huſband is my foe—
My huſband? No, it ſurely cannot be:
That tender title is no longer his;
I am no more his wife. The tie's deſolv'd—
I here renounce his name, with ſolemn oath,
To be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: May I, kind lady, hope to have that place,
In thy eſteem, which he has forfeited?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: In gratitude for all thy kindneſſes,
And from the warneſt ſentiments of love,
My honour'd friend, thou mayſt.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Immortal happineſs be thy reward!
And here be pleas'd to take this miniature,
Which is my repreſentative, to ſhow,
That I devote my heart to thee alone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: My heart it ſolely thine. Accept this ring,
And let it be a token of my love.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: O may I be the bleſſing of thy life!

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: And I remain thy ever-faithful wife!
My happineſs is now at length compleat:
For paſt diſtreſs, makes preſent joy more ſweet.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: The ſun ne'er ſhone on ſuch a day as this,
That ſeals my title to conſummate bliſs.

div.trailer: The END of the FOURTH ACT.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: BEFORE to-morrow's dawn,
His veſſel will be moving under ſail;
And e'er the ſun aſcend half way to noon,
Leave Boſton harbour, if the wind prove fair.
I've hir'd the Captain and a private hand
(Two truſty fellows, whom we need not fear)
To help us kill the man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: How is the buſineſs to be done?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: We are to ſmother him aſleep,
If ſlumber cloſe his drowſy eyes; if not,
Some other meaſure is to be purſu'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I ſhudder at the horrid ſcene.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: It is a horrid ſcene, be ſure;
But 'tis a momentary one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: And how to be conceal'd?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: The Captain will attend to that;
He will, in ſilence, carry him away,
To be entomb'd amidſt the roaring waves;
Then repreſent him fallen overboard.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: A good device! But is this Captain firm?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: As firm as fate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I wiſh the bloody buſineſs were perform'd.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: An hour or two will bring the end;
All things are ready for the deed.
Let us anticipate our future ſtate,
When ſmiling love ſhall lead at hand in hand,
O'er blooming regions of connubial joy;
Then, lovely fait-one, then—God ſpeed the day!—
Oh! Then adieu to groans and tears and ſighs,
We'll trip along the flowery vale of life,
And ſing and dance and ſport away our cares.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Bleſt period of my life!
I ſee it, as a diſtant eminence:
But thorns and briars fill the ſpace between.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Waſte not a thought on that:
The period ſoon will come, to bleſs our eyes.
Fly, lingering moments, ſwiftly urge your flight,
To bear away the intervening time;
Then drop your wings, deſcend, and walk with us.
What ſcenes of dalliance open to our view!
Love makes a paradiſe on earth. [Sings.]
When Adam, in the days of yore,
Enjoy'd all nature's ample ſtore,
In Eden's blisful ſeat,
Amidſt that ſolitary ſtate,
He wanted nothimg but a mate,
To render him compleat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: A pretty ſong! You have a lovely voice;
A charming voice you have; It pleaſes me.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: And me no leſs, becauſe it pleaſes you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: How ſweet is muſic to the mourning ſoul!

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: As ſweet as honey, and as pure as light.
When, through the portal of the liſtening ear,
Soft muſic enters and ſalutes the ſoul,
It ſoon diſpels the frowning cloud of care,
Bids faded melancholy yield a ſmile,
And ſorrow wipe away the ſtarting tear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: I love to hear your voice.
Have you no other ſong?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Another verſe of this.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Well, let me hear the whole.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: With all my heart. Sings again.
As Adam then, without his bride,
Though bleſs with every thing beſide,
Was reſtleſs, while alone:
So now in wedlock let us ſhare
Of ſocial bliſs and mutual core,
And Eden is our own.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Moſt happily performed! I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: No thanks, my dear;
Reward me rather with a kiſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Dear Sir! [kiſſes her.] You are too complaiſant.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: You have too many charms.
Were I as fickle as the changing wind,
I ſhould forever be entirely yours;
For I'm the happieſt man alive.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I ſhould be happy, if this night were paſt.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Pray, think of that no more. 'Twill ſoon be gone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: I ſtrive to baniſh it, but can't;
It hangs upon my mind.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Be not concern'd; The hours are on the wing;
And I muſt bring the Captain near at hand.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: May ſafety be your guide.
Lord! How the Major talks and ſings!
His very nature is brim full of love.
What happy hours I could enjoy with him,
If this long night were number'd with the paſt!
I wonder Mr. Jenſon don't return;
And yet the fatal moment is too nigh.
It is a pity I have gone ſo far;
A real pity: But I can't go back;
And therefore—Hold—Who comes? 'Tis he, I think—
Who elſe?—It ſounds like Mr. Worthy's voice.
I'll ſtand aſide, and hear their talk.

div.stage: Mrs. Jenſon goes into a cloſet; and Meſſrs. Worthy and Jenſon enter converſing together.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Thou wilt remit intelligence
Of thy ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: By every opportunity, I will.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Thy country's happineſs
Is truſted to thy care—A weighty truſt!

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: I feel its weight.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: O happy country! Bleſt UNITED STATES

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: As great in arts of peace, as martial deeds

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: The ſtorm of war, that hover'd o'er our ſhores
And threaten'd ruin, is diſpers'd and gone.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: The glorious ſun-ſhine of reviving peace
Breaks out, to chear this land of liberty.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Theſe are the works of our Almighty Friend;
Thanks to his name, that I behold this day.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: He rules and reigns: Let all the earth rejoice.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: The world is his. By his ſupreme command,
Day follows Night, and Night ſucceeds to Day.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: Week after Week appears, and paſſes on.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Swift Months purſue declining Months around.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: Cold Winter melts, before the Summer's heat;

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: And Summer ſhrinks, before the Winter's cold.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: Years tread the ſteps of antecedent Years.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: One Generation ruſh acroſs the ſtage;
And others cloſely follow, at their heels.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: One Empire lifts its head, looks round, then falls;
And other Empires riſe upon its back.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: The whirling Earth revokes upon itſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: The circling Planets, wheel about the Sun.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Whole ſolar ſyſtems round their centre move:

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: And that, with others, round one common point.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Thus ſpreads the motion, through immenſity.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: The harmony of nature thus is form'd.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: He moves and governs theſe revolving worlds.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: He holds the univerſe within his hand.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: He is our GOD.

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: JEHOVAH is his name.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: May he preſerve theſe riſing States from harm!

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: May he enlarge their ſtrength and happineſs!

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: God crown thy foreign labours with ſucceſs!

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.p: God give you peace and unity at home.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Adieu, my friend;

sp.speaker: Mr. J.
sp.l: Reſpected Sir, adieu. Mr. Worthy retires.
My papers are convey'd on board;
It two o'clock I am to go myſelf.
See, it is now a little after twelve.
Two hours almoſt I have for ſleep. Retires.
He's gone. I cannot envy his repoſe.
〈…〉 ! He don't at all ſuſpect,
What miſchief we intend againſt his life.
It ſeems too much, altough he is a knave—
A monſtrous knave, to violate his truth,
And afterward inſult my miſery.
Nay, he is juſtly doom'd to ſuffer death;
This night is proper for the work.—How dark!
How ſtill and melancholy too it is!
I tremble at myſelf—What noiſe is that?—
The Major's lonely ſteps:—Yes, ſure it is.
But where's your Captain and his Hand?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Without the door.
Has Mr. Jenſon gone to ſleep?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: He has retir'd to reſt.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: It happens well. Goes out again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Now, now, the bloody moment has arriv'd.

div.stage: Enter Major Shapely, Captain and Sailor.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: We come prepar'd to execute revenge.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Come, let us take a bitter, gentlemen,
To fit us for this bitter work.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Ah! Bitter in the higheſt ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: By Paddy, we will make it ſweet enough.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A glaſs of bitters would not be amiſs.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: He is no ſailor, upon my ſoul, who cannot unfill his glaſs, in time of need.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Security to our attempt. Pretends to drink.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Faith, that is what we want.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Zounds! Give me ſecurity, and I will meet the devil, face to face, any day.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Both ſilence and ſecurity
To our attempt.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: Come, Sir,
A flowing glaſs,
And a pretty laſs, is a ſailor's toaſt.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Aye, and a ſoldier's too.
Are all your weapons ready?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Mine are,

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: And mine, by Jove.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Now, to the work.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: We are compleatly man'd. Lead on:
For you are pilot in this voyage.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Aſſiſt us, all ye gloomy powers of night!

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Do kill him quick.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: He dies, as quick as a flaſh of lightning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Remember to prevent his groans.

div.stage: Major Shapely, Captain and Sailor go out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: A trying time! Kind heav'n deliver me!
Oh, impious pray'r! How dare I lift mine eyes,
To follow my petitions up to heav'n,
For bleſſing on a murderer? Ah me!
Where ſhall I go? Whence can I ſeek defence?
My grief! What awful ſhadows hang around!
A murderous ſcene! and is this murder then?
No, it is juſtce—nothing more—Why not?
Deſtracting thought! [groaning within.] Alas! That frightful ſound!
It is his groan. [groaning a ſecond time.] Again! Mercy on me!
Yet hark—how my heart beats!—Be huſh'd—no more—
'Tis done. He is diſpatch'd.—How? What diſpach'd?
Where am I? [ſtarting up.] Where has Major Shapely? gone?
Ten thouſand horrors fill this lonely place:
It ſeems to me like ſome enchauned ground.
Am I awake, or is this all a dream?
Ah? There he comes. How tall and pale he looks!

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: My dear!

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: I: Don't you know my voice?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Oh! Yes; what news?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: All's well. The traytor is no more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Was he awake?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: At firſt we thought him faſt aſleep;
And crept along to ſmother him in bed:
But he began to ſtir, and raiſe himſelf;
Then we rusſh'd on. This dagger—

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: That inſtrument of death;
Look, how it drops with blood!

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: It met his riſing breaſt;
And, urg'd with fury, pierc'd him through and through.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Poor man! I heard him ſhriek.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: He ſhriek'd indeed;
And, falling faintly back upon the bed,
Exclaim'd, O Shapely! Is it thou?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: My fears were true;
Such accents indiſtinctly reach'd mine ears.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: I fear'd he would have wak'd the family.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Tremendous ſight! How did he look?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: He look'd ſo tenderly at me,
His anguiſh fixt a dagger in my ſoul.
I try'd to ſpeak: But horror froze my tongue;
A chilling tremor ran through every nerve.
In ſpite of all my pride, I burſt in tears.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: 'Twould force a tear from cruelty itſelf.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: With eyes roll'd back, he groan'd a ſecond time;
And, wildly ſtruggling in the pangs of death,
Diſcharg'd at me his vital breath.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Don't tell me any more: 'Twill make me faint.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: It was too much for me. I turn'd aſide—
[Hollowing within.] What means that hideous cry?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Mercy protect me!

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: The men are drunk; I am afraid,
Their poiſon has begun to operate.
sp.stage: [Goes to the door, and opening it, Betty ruſhes in.]
sp.l: Hah! [ſtarting back.] What's the matter here?
Are you diſtracted?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: They've murder'd Mr. Jenſon in his bed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Why Betty!

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: For ſhame, be ſtill. You are aſleep.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I wiſh I were: But this has ſtartled me awake.

sp.speaker: Shap.
