sp.l: Not more than half, as I am here alive.
Your ſenſes are perhaps awake; but ſtill
Your reaſon and your judgment are aſleep,
Or you would never prattle thus.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Come then yourſelf, and be convinc'd.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: There ſtop that bawling wench, or ſhe will run us all aground.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Oh, murder!

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Silence.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.l: I muſt not, will not hold my peace.
Help, ho! murder! murder!

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Let's kill the ſtrumpet.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: What! kill me too?

div.stage: [Runs out doors and the Sailor after her.]

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: No, fetch her back. Be cautious.
Confuſion take her! She will raiſe the town.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Can't we hide?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: I know no place.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: There is none.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: Dear me! What ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Deny the fact,
And charge it on the ſailors.

div.stage: The Sailor enters, leading in Betty muffled.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: She hollow'd, murder! once or twice, as if the devil ſwell'd her voice.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Did any body hear her?

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: The Lord can tell, much better than I can.
Now, by Saint Patrick, you ſhall die.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: No, hold; don't injure her.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Where then ſhall I ſtow her?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: No matter where.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: See her well muffled firſt,
Then ſhut her in the cloſet there.

div.stage: A Neighbour enters with a light.

sp.speaker: Neigh.
sp.l: What is the cauſe of this alarm?
Is any body murder'd?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: It is a falſe alarm. No hurt is done.

sp.speaker: Neigh.
sp.p: It has awak'd the town, at any rate.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I'm ſorry. 'Twas an accident.
We've a diſtracted perſon—There ſhe fit:—
Who juſt now happen'd to get off her chains,
And run out ſcreaming, through the ſtreets,
Like Bediam. That is all. Pray haſten back,
And ſtop the horrid cry, before it ſpread.

sp.speaker: Neigh.
sp.l: There's ſomething more;
What means that dagger in your hand?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: What this? Raiſing it up.

sp.speaker: Neigh.
sp.p: Hah! Bloody too?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I've bound him up.

sp.speaker: Neigh.
sp.p: What? Bound up whom?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Heav'ns! Who art thou?

sp.speaker: Neigh.
sp.p: There's murder here, I ſay.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Worthy, Officers and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Who's murder'd is this houſe?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: Defend me, Major Shapely;
Do let me lean upon thine arm. Swoons.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: For God's ſake, let me call the Doctor in.

sp.speaker: Neigh.
sp.l: He is a knave,

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Then ſtop him, Officer, and ſtore them all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You 〈◊〉 upon your death.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Stand off, I ſay, ſtand off from me, or by my life, I'll give you a broad-ſide that will ſink you to the ground.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Fear not his threats.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: Reſign yourſelves, or take the conſequence.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: O guilt!
I cannot fight; 〈◊〉 ſomething 〈◊〉 to my arm. Submits.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Then yield, you heartleſs coward, and be hang'd,
I'll fight no more in your defence.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Nor I, by George, I'll ſee you drown'd in fire and brimſtone firſt.

div.stage: Officer and others ſieze Shapely, Captain and Sailor.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: [Let looſe.] They've kill'd my maſter.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Who have?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Thoſe curſed Sailors.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Ungrateful dog!
He hir'd us to aſſiſt. We did no more.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Unhappy woman! See, ſhe has at fit.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Bind all the raſcals faſt.
My God! Is this in 〈◊〉 ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: [Reviving.] O Major Shapely! Where art thou? Faints again.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: My dear, I can't afford thee any aid;
Endeavours are in vain: Our all is loſs.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Where is this victim of their murderous guilt?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: In that room, there.

div.stage: Mr. Worthy and others go out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.p: [Reviving.] Murder my huſband!

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Don't mind it, dear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. J.
sp.l: I muſt. It haunts my guilty thoughts.
Deſtruction! Oh! What furies hover round,
In haſte to ſnatch me to the horrid pit,
Which yawns, and frightens back my flattering ſoul!
Yet nature ſinks—Death pulls me down a main—
Oh! Oh! I leap eternal precipice.
Adieu. [dies.]

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Her dying gaſp! See, ſhe is gone.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: I'll follow her. Attempts to ſtab himſelf.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Hold, villain. Are you not diſarm'd?
There, wait your proper time.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Not ſuffer me to die a ſoldier's death?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: No, you ſhall be reſerv'd,
To grace a rope, on gallows hill.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: There is no remedy; I muſt ſubmit.
Diſgraceful death, and ſomething worſe beyond!
That thought lights up damnation in my breaſt;
Hell ſtares me in the face, with all its pains.
Oh, darkneſs and deſpair!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Now ſay, the ſailors did the crime.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I lied.
I am a liar, coward, murderer,
And any thing, the worſt you can invent.
I've murder'd you, as well as him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, not ſo bad, for I am yet alive.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: But death is planted in your blood.
You drank a poiſon'd dram, that I had mix'd,
Leſt you hereafter ſhould divulge the fact:

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: And I too?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Both alike.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Am I then poiſon'd?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: To death, you are.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Certainly? What, by that glaſs of bitters?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: That very glaſs.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: O murder heap'd on murder's head!
This is the conſequence of being brib'd,
To ſtrangle other people in their ſleep.
A ſenſe of that at once diſarms my tongue,
Which elſe would curſe you, to the loweſt hell—
Don't roll thoſe guilty, ſnakiſh eyes this way;
You ſcatter poiſon with your very looks.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: Methinks, I feel it working in my veins,
Like ſpiders crawling over all my fleſh.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Pray, give me leave to cruſh that viper's head.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: No, let the hangman do his work.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: As quick as poſſible:
For, like a hateful, poiſon-ſucking toad,
This villain has attracted all the guilt,
Within a hundred miles; and hanging him
Will purge the land.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: Oh, horror, guilt and death!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Rejoice, O honeſt world! rejoice,
When this adept in villany is dead:
But bluſh, ye monſters of the lower realms,
To ſee yourſelves out-devil'd by a man.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Worthy, and Attendants bringing in Mr. Jenſon's body.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Here lay him down.
See Mrr Jenſon's mangl'd corps.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: And here behold the wretch, who mangled him.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Inhuman act!
Look how his garments are beſmear'd with blood,
Still ſtreaming from his wound! Obſerve his eyes—
Not thoſe bright ſtars, that lately ſparkled there;
But glaſſy balls, roll'd up in ſtupid glare.
I'll gently cloſe his lids.—There, ſleep, my friend,
Poor bleeding, murder'd friend, repoſe in death.
Thoſe cheeks, which ••• ely bloom'd with youthful ſmiles,
Are nothing now, alas! but ghaſtly clods,
Death ſets in triumph on his wither'd face.
That tongue, which ably plead his country's cauſe,
Is ſtiff? And all his limbs refuſe to move.
How will his friends and country mourn his death,
A private, and no leſs a public loſs!
Juſt mounting to the ſtage of public life,
Seiz'd by a murderer's hand, and plung'd in death!

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.p: 'Twas I who murder'd him.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Thou child of darkneſs!
Why didſt thou perpetrate the helliſh deed?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: To ſatiate my deſires.
The love of happineſs has been my bane;
For this, through peaceful calms and ſtorms of ſtrife,
I've travel'd round the globe of human life;
At length, my race of villany is run,
My guilt compleated and my journey done.
Farewell, ſweet hope! expected bliſs, farewell!
Come, dire deſpair, thou blackeſt imp of hell,
With all the plagues, that form thy curſed train,
Remorſe and envy, jealouſy and pain;
Come, from the realms of miſery below,
And take me down to everlaſting woe.

div.trailer: The END of the FIFTH ACT.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: TO generous ſouls, whoſe ſentiments are right▪
The exerciſe of candour gives delight▪
But other perſons, of a different make,
Rejoice to find and cenſure a miſtake.
As every audience is compoſed of theſe,
This evening's play muſt conſequently pleaſe:
For here are faults of almoſt every name,
That candour can forgive, or cenſure blome.
Ye critics, then, and patrons of the ſtage.
The juſt reſiners of the preſent age,
Who fill, adorn and dignify theſe ſeats,
Pray, grant this ſavour, which your friend entreats;
Be good enough our foibles to excuſe,
Indulge the boldneſs of a youthfull muſe,
And thus declare to each unbiaſs'd mind,
That ſkilful judges are moſt freely kind.
